newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ'S BIRCH HINTS AT ABATEMENT REGIME FOR PENSIONS.
newsitem.headline: NZ'S BIRCH HINTS AT ABATEMENT REGIME FOR PENSIONS.

text.p: Finance Minister Bill Birch said on Thursday that if the compulsory pension scheme is rejected in September an abatement regime might have to be considered.
New Zealanders vote in a referendum in September on compulsory superannuation, something that Birch himself said he was personally against.
The current scheme is seen as unsustainable because of the ageing population.

"It does seem to me personally just common sense that, if the public does not endorse compulsion, abatement would be one measure considered as a contribution to fiscal stability, and to retirement income security in the future," Birch said in speech notes to a Palmerston North business forum.
Birch is in favour of the abolition of the current pension surcharge, saying it was poorly designed legislation.

Alternatively, Birch said, instead of a relatively high super payment abated for rising income it might be equally possible to consider a lower but relatively universal payment, topped up at the bottom end for retired people in genuine need.
Birch also suggested the age of eligibility be raised over time to compensate for people living longer.
"Changes will certainly be necessary," he said.
Birch said multi-party consensus was hugely desirable on the issue of pensions.
